awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Leveraging the Effect of Nanoscale Roughness on Macroscale Adhesion
awd_abstract_narration:
Many of the modern technologies produce miniaturized devices used in applications from electronics, communications, medicine as well as others. The small size of these devices leads to unique issues in their manufacture and use. However, many of these emerging devices and manufacturing techniques face a problem with stickiness or adhesion. Specifically, when small-size parts come into contact, they spontaneously stick together and cannot easily be pulled apart. This problem significantly limits the performance and reliability of otherwise promising technologies. This grant supports fundamental research to understand the dependence of adhesion on surface roughness. This project will develop new ways to measure roughness at small sizes, and also new ways to control it. Ultimately, the insights gained from this investigation will enable the intentional modification of roughness during manufacturing to improve the performance of the final devices. The investigation is being conducted by an international team of researchers, and incorporates specific programs for education both for engineers in industry to put the research into practice, and also for grade-school students to increase interest and participation among the next generation of American engineers. 

The goals of this award are: (1) to identify the length scales of surface roughness that most strongly impact adhesion; and (2) to develop fabrication strategies to rationally modify topography at these scales to control adhesion. First, the investigation will use transmission electron microscopy to characterize previously unmeasured scales of topography on technologically-relevant materials, and then use a custom micromechanical tester to measure their surface adhesion. Experimental results will be analyzed in the context of existing analytical and numerical models, in order to evaluate and then improve these models. The experiments will be complemented by large-scale computer simulations of identical surfaces, in order to gain atomic-scale information about the material response. The simulations will be carried out through a strong non-NSF-funded collaboration with the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology in Germany. Second, using advanced lithographic techniques, the small-scale roughness of test surfaces will be systematically varied and quantitatively linked to changes in properties. This will enable both experimental tests of rough-surface models, as well as the demonstration of routes to modify surface roughness to achieve an optimal surface adhesion. This investigation will have direct impact on microscale devices and on advanced manufacturing, both of which require precise understanding and control of surface properties. Further, the experimental validation of roughness models will have application to rough surfaces more broadly from automotive components to road surfaces to medical implants.

por.por_cntn:
In consumer electronics and biomedical applications, microscopic devices are currently used for many purposes, such as to detect motion, record sound, and measure blood pressure. However, many of these emerging devices face a problem with stickiness ? or adhesion. Specifically, when small-size parts come into contact, they spontaneously stick together and cannot easily be pulled apart. This problem significantly limits the performance and reliability of otherwise promising technologies. This project conducted fundamental research to understand the dependence of adhesion on surface roughness.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in its uncovering of four key findings about the influence of nanoscale roughness on large-scale adhesion. First, we developed a novel approach to characterizing roughness across all length scales from the device scale down to the atomic scale. Second, we leveraged this novel understanding of roughness to shed light on various applications from the friction of walking shoes to the fatigue performance of 3D-printed metals. Third, we demonstrated novel understanding of the adhesion of hard materials in contact. Specifically, we used sphere-on-flat contacts of ruby on diamond to show the importance of plasticity in determining hard-material adhesion, and that there is a critical band of size scales (between 43 nanometers and 1.8 microns) which has the strongest effect on adhesion of these contacts. Fourth, we uncovered novel insights into the adhesion and friction of soft materials on hard, rough surfaces: establishing new models to describe the adhesive contact of soft materials, and their adhesion-induced friction during sliding.

To maximize the impact of these scientific findings, the work has been disseminated widely to the scientific community and broader public. Specifically, the work has resulted in nine journal publications (8 published, 1 accepted) with six more either submitted or in preparation. All of these publications are either in open-access journals, or have had versions posted to repositories so that they can be freely and easily accessed. As an example of the response from the scientific community, one of those publications already has 250 citations at the time of completion of the project, more than any other article in the history of the journal that it was published in. Additionally, the team have given 19 presentations on the work at major conferences, with four of those as invited talks.

The broader impacts of this project have taken two forms: technological and educational. Technologically, the team has developed  a freely-available web application, for use in research and industry settings, which implements our findings in an easily accessible way. Specifically, users can upload their topography measurements and, at the touch of a button, the web app will perform advanced topographic analysis as well as contact-mechanics calculations. The web app has already seen good engagement by the community, with more than 4000 surfaces uploaded and more than 40,000 analyses performed.

Educationally, the project has contributed to science education events put on by the Society for Women Engineers (SWE), and the National Society for Black Engineers (NSBE). In total, these roughness-focused outreach activities reached more than 200 students of middle-school, high-school, and university ages. Additionally, the project has involved collaboration with other Universities both in the US and internationally, as well as with a national laboratory.  Finally, work on this project has led to the mentorship of fifteen junior researchers, involving four graduate students, two postdocs, and nine undergraduate students.
